required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pharmacodynamic Interactions of Propofol and Dexmedetomidine on Intravenous Anesthesia
clinical_study.official_title: Pharmacodynamic Interactions of Propofol and Dexmedetomidine on Target-controlled Infusion Intravenous Anesthesia During the Induction

lead_sponsor.agency: Guangzhou General Hospital of Guangzhou Military Command

clinical_study.source: Guangzhou General Hospital of Guangzhou Military Command

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine pharmacodynamic interactions of propofol and dexmedetomidine,exploring the effect of dexmedetomidine on propofol unconsciousness median effective concentration (EC50).

detailed_description.textblock: 64 cases were randomly divided into four groups, In each group, dexmedetomidine target plasma concentration are 0, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 ng/ml. Dexmedetomidine administered 15 min before target controlled infusion of propofol. The propofol infusion was started to provide a target effect-site concentration of 1.0ug/ml, and increased by 0.2ug/ml until loss of consciousness when the effect-site concentration and target concentration equilibrium.

primary_outcome.measure: The EC50 of propofol for loss of consciousness
primary_outcome.time_frame: within 30 min during the induction of anesthesia
primary_outcome.description: The aim of the investigators study is to define the optimum target concentration (EC50) of propofol for loss of consciousness with different dexmedetomidine target plasm concentration.

secondary_outcome.measure: The EC95 of propofol for loss of consciousness
secondary_outcome.time_frame: within 30 min during the induction of anesthesia
secondary_outcome.description: The aim of the investigators study is to define the optimum target concentration (EC95) of propofol for loss of consciousness with different dexmedetomidine target plasm concentration.

arm_group.description: Propofol infusion was started to provide an effect-site concentration of 1.0ug/ml after Dexmedetomidine which target plasma concentration is 0.0ng/ml administered for 15min, and increased by 0.2ug/ml until the patient's consciousness disappears.

Propofol infusion was started to provide an effect-site concentration of 1.0ug/ml after Dexmedetomidine which target plasma concentration is 0.4ng/ml administered for 15min, and increased by 0.2ug/ml until the patient's consciousness disappears.

Propofol infusion was started to provide an effect-site concentration of 1.0ug/ml after Dexmedetomidine which target plasma concentration is 0.6ng/ml administered for 15min, and increased by 0.2ug/ml until the patient's consciousness disappears.

Propofol infusion was started to provide an effect-site concentration of 1.0ug/ml after Dexmedetomidine which target plasma concentration is 0.8ng/ml administered for 15min, and increased by 0.2ug/ml until the patient's consciousness disappears.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Weight:18≦ BMI≦25
2. Written informed consent from the patient or the relatives of the participating patient.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. A previous history of intolerance to the study drug or related compounds and additives.
2. Existing significant haematological, endocrine, metabolic or gastrointestinal disease.

facility.name: Guangzhou Military Region General Hospital, Department of Anesthesiology

reference.citation: Chen Z, Shao DH, Hang LH. Effects of dexmedetomidine on performance of bispectral index as an indicator of loss of consciousness during propofol administration. Swiss Med Wkly. 2013 Mar 14;143:w13762. doi: 10.4414/smw.2013.13762.

Hannivoort LN, Eleveld DJ, Proost JH, Reyntjens KM, Absalom AR, Vereecke HE, Struys MM. Development of an Optimized Pharmacokinetic Model of Dexmedetomidine Using Target-controlled Infusion in Healthy Volunteers. Anesthesiology. 2015 Aug;123(2):357-67. doi: 10.1097/ALN.0000000000000740.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Guangzhou General Hospital of Guangzhou Military Command
